awd_titl_txt: Training courses on the matrix approach to modeling land carbon and nitrogen cycles; 2018-2021: Flagstaff, AZ
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will train early career scientists and develop the U.S. workforce. The training will occur through a series of short courses on the topic of land carbon and nitrogen cycles. Carbon and nitrogen are both important for human well-being and ecosystem function. Land ecosystems absorb approximately 30% of current carbon dioxide emissions by humans. We need further details about how this happens. To improve models that can provide these details, scientists have recently developed a new technique called the matrix approach. The matrix approach has been recognized as a way to unify all the land carbon cycle models. There are additional benefits from this approach that involve understanding uncertainty, reducing computation time, and merging data into the models. The approach has the potential to improve land carbon and nitrogen models to better predict future changes in ecosystem services. The courses will train a new generation of ecosystem modelers to achieve simplicity in coding, cleaner and more efficient models, faster results, and a better bridge between model complexity and understandable results. 

This project will run an annual short training course for the next three years. The topic of the course is modeling land carbon and nitrogen cycles. The specific approach is called the matrix approach. The course will focus on five skills to be trained: (1) drawing the carbon flow diagram of a model; (2) writing carbon balance equations of a model; (3) developing a matrix model out of carbon balance equations; (4) adding diagnostic variables; and (5) adding semi-analytic spin-up algorithms. The hands-on training will be combined with lectures on a variety of topics. The topics will be: theories of land carbon cycle dynamics, data assimilation, matrix operation, differential equation solvers, and model structure databases. The training course will divide the trainees into several working groups, each with one instructor to ensure individual help. The course will be improved to become more effective and efficient over time as feedback from trainees is incorporated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate change and the consequent climate extremes represent major threats to Earth. Mitigating climate change relies on accurate predictions of global carbon (C) cycle. Several challenges exist in modeling land C cycle, e.g., large model uncertainty and high computational cost that prevent big data to be integrated with big models, which all hinder our understanding and predictions of land C sink and their feedback to climate change.

This project aimed to train young scientists the matrix approach to: 1) diagnose model uncertainty with a suite of new diagnostic variables; 2) accelerate model spin-up; 3) conduct pool-based data assimilation; and 4) explore theories in biogeochemistry to modeling land carbon and nitrogen cycles. The ultimate goal is to predict future changes in ecosystem services and feedback to climate change more accurately with land biogeochemical models.

We have organized five training courses in 2018-2022 (one week in 2018 and two-week in 2019-2022). The training course was in person in 2018 and 2019, virtual in 2020 and 2021, and hybrid (virtual + in person) in 2022. Total 445 participants from 37 countries have attended the five training courses. Most of them are graduate students, post-docs and assistant professors, so the training course is helpful for their career development.

We have taught six new techniques in modeling land carbon and nitrogen cycles: matrix approach, data assimilation, benchmark analysis, ecological forecasting, machine learning, and process-based machine learning. Each of the six techniques for modeling is systematically organized from theories to case studies that demonstrate their applications to address scientific questions, and finally to practice sessions to gain hand-on experience of these techniques using the software CarboTrain. CarboTrain is the software developed for the practice sessions. CarboTrain made the practice sessions more consistent across units and allowed all our participants to finish the practice tasks smoothly, including those participants without much modeling and programming background but eager to applying modeling techniques for data-model integration studies.  

To introduce to the participants about the cutting-edge knowledge and the major challenges in land carbon and nitrogen cycles, we invited leading scientists in the field of biogeochemistry from all over the world to give invited talks each year.

We have published a textbook entitled "Land Carbon Cycle Modeling: Matrix Approach, Data Assimilation, & Ecological Forecasting" based on materials that were developed and used in this training course. As in the training course, the textbook covers not only theories of the modeling techniques we trained, but also step-by-step instructions on how to practice these techniques with the software CarboTrain. In addition, there are also corresponding videos for each chapter of the textbook. All these resources are publicly accessible for free, and researchers can use them in their own teaching or research. 

Spinning off from the training course, we formed three working groups with volunteers from participants of the training course in 2020 and 2021 to extend their learning of modeling techniques through a "learning by doing' process. The learning process of these working groups started from designing a study, to carrying out the study, and finally to finishing a manuscript from the working group study.  

We have developed a platform to diagnose model uncertainty with the matrix approach by the working group formed in 2021. It is an open, transparent, and reproduceable platform with a clear documentation for users to use it easily. The platform consists of two modules: module I is matrix representation of land C cycle models and module II is uncertainty analysis of simulated land C storage. It is a unique infrastructure with two interconnected functions: unifying land C cycle models in the matrix form and diagnosing model uncertainty through traceability analysis. We have applied the platform to compare Dynamic Global Vegetation Models (DGVMs) involved in the TRENDY project. Modelers, experimentalists, and resource managers can use this platform for building their own matrix models or for Model Intercomparison Projects (MIPs).  

Through this project, we have advanced our predictive understating of land C and N cycles under climate change by applying the newly developed modeling techniques to integrate big data into land biogeochemical models. More reliable predictions of land C and N cycles under climate change can help better mitigate climate change. Therefore, the training course contributes to mitigation of climate change and thus sustainability of our planet.
